member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRuleType
member.summary: Constants which describe the production rules which are used by the associated Grammar.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRuleType.None
member.summary: Used for variable declaration.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRuleType.Terminal
member.summary: A rule consisting of a single TerminalSymbol. A 'Terminal' rule cannot have sub-rules; attempting to add a sub-rule for a terminal rule will cause an exception to be thrown. A terminal rule is analogous to a leaf node of a parse tree; text is compared to the terminal symbol's value to decide whether the rule is satisfied.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRuleType.NonTerminal
member.summary: A rule consisting of a single NonTerminalSymbol.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRuleType.Alternation
member.summary: A logical 'OR' is applied between each of the sub-rules. If any of the sub-rules match the text being compared in the tex being validated, the rule is considered to have been satisfied. This rule is represented symbolically in EBNF by separating each individual subrule with the '|' character. Example: ('A' | 'B'); the rule is satisfied if either 'A' or 'B' is satisfied.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRuleType.Concatenation
member.summary: A rule containing one or more sub-rules, which are expected to be satisfied in sequential order. Each of the sub-rules must parse text from the input string for the rule to be considered to have been satisfied. This rule is represented symbolically in EBNF by separating each individual subrule with the ',' character. Example: ('A', 'B'); the rule is satisfied if 'A' is satisfied, and, after the text associated with 'A' is consumed, 'B' is also satisfied.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRuleType.Conjunction
member.summary:
The first sub-rule is evaluated and if it fails, the Conjunction rule fails as well. If the first rule succeeds, the token it produces is then evaluated by subsequent rules and if all rules succeed, the first token's string is consumed and parsing continues.
Note: Only the following rules can exist in the descendant chain of a Conjunction rule:
TerminalRule
NonTerminalRule
AlternationRule
ConjunctionRule
NegationRule
Adding any other rule to the Rules collection of the ConjunctionRule, or that of any of its descendants, causes an InvalidDescendantOfConjunctionRuleException to be thrown.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRuleType.Optional
member.summary: Each of the sub-rules may or may not be satisfied when evaluating the text being validated. This rule is also known as "zero or one". This rule is represented symbolically in EBNF by enclosing each individual sub-rule within square brackets, i.e., the list is preceded with a '[' character and terminated with a ']' character. Example: ['A' | 'B']; the rule is satisfied if either 'A' or 'B' is satisfied, and also if neither 'A' nor 'B' is satisfied. The 'Optional' rule is the equivalent of a 'Repetition' rule with a minimum of 0 and a maximum of 1.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRuleType.Repetition
member.summary:
Each of the sub-rules may be repeated x or more times, and no more than y times, where x and y represent the minimum and maximum number of allowed occurrences, respectively. The 'Repetition' rule is satisfied if each sub-rule is satisfied at least the minimum number of repetitions, and not exceeding the maximum number of repetitions. The 'Repetition' rule has multiple symbolic representations in EBNF, depending on the different variations of minimum/maximum combinations. Enclosing a statement within curly braces ('{' and '}') specifies that the statement is evaluated repeatedly until it fails, and is satisfied whether it yields zero or more occurrences. Using the Kleene operator ("*") specifies an explicit number of expected occurrences. This mode of expression is also referred to as a syntactic factor. Examples:
{'A'}: The 'Repetition' rule is satisfied whether rule 'A' is satisfied or not, and 'A' may be repeated any number of times. If one or more descendant rules of 'A' is satisfied, but not all of them are, the 'Repetition' rule fails. If no descendant rules of 'A' are satisfied, or if all of them are, the 'Repetition' rule is satisfied. In this example, the minimum is set to 0 and the maximum is not enforced. Assuming 'A' is a terminal rule which expects a literal string, "A", this rule is satisfied if a number of occurrences of the string "A" is encountered in succession, and also if it is not encountered at all. If it is encountered, the parsing layer consumes each occurrence of the character, and the parsing operation continues.
(3 * 'A'): The 'Repetition' rule is satisfied if and only if rule 'A' is satisfied exactly three times in succession. In this example, the minimum and maximum are both set to 3. Assuming 'A' is a terminal rule which expects a literal string, "A", this rule is satisfied only if the string "AAA" is encountered. If it is encountered, the parsing layer consumes all three characters, and the validation operation continues.
(* 'A'): Same as the previous example, except that the syntactic factor is implied to be one, since no number was specified.
(3 * ['A']): The 'Repetition' rule is satisfied if rule 'A' is satisfied zero, one, two, or three times in succession. In this example, the minimum is set to zero and the maximum is set to 3.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.SyntaxRuleType.Negation
member.summary:
A rule containing one or more sub-rules which are explicitly disallowed in order for the rule to be satisfied.
Note: As with the Conjunction rule, only the following rules can exist in the descendant chain of a Negation rule:
TerminalRule
NonTerminalRule
AlternationRule
ConjunctionRule
NegationRule
Adding any other rule to the Rules collection of the Negation, or that of any of its descendants, causes an InvalidDescendantOfConjunctionRuleException to be thrown.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbolComparison.Literal
member.summary: The value associated with the symbol is a literal string. The syntax parser will compare values in the compilation target with the associated value and generate an error if the values do not match exactly. The comparison under this setting is case-sensitive.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbolComparison.LiteralIgnoreCase
member.summary: Same as the 'Literal' setting, except that character casing is ignored for the string comparisons.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbolComparison.RegularExpression
member.summary: The value associated with the symbol is implied to be a regular expression pattern. The System._Text.RegularExpressions.Regex class is used to determine whether values in the compilation target match the pattern assigned to the terminal symbol's value.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbolParseResult.CaseInsensitiveMatch
member.summary: A case-insensitive match was made, i.e., the text was the same but case differed between the value and the input.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbolParseResult.PatternMatch
member.summary: The input matched the terminal's regex pattern.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbolParseResult.NoMatch
member.summary: No match was made.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbolParseResult.MatchWithoutBoundary
member.summary: A match was made, but was not followed by the expected boundary pattern.

member.name: F:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.ParseErrorReason.Negation

member.summary: The input stream has been consumed in its entirety, but one or more rules have not yet been evaluated.

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar
member.summary: Encapsulates a formal, context-free grammar whose production rules are used to parse and validate textual input.

remarks.p: The syntax of a programming language is defined by its grammar. This formal definition provides a way to define what constitutes a legal sequence of characters in a concise, unambiguous manner.

A syntax analyzer is a finite state machine which evaluates textual input according to the rules defined within the grammar, determining whether the input conforms to these rules. The starting point for syntax analysis is exposed through the StartSymbol property. Syntax analysis is realized by recursively iterating the start symbol's Rules collection.
The main components of a grammar definition are encapsulated by the TerminalSymbol and NonTerminalSymbol classes.

A TerminalSymbol represents the string or pattern which must be matched in order for the corresonding rule to be satisfied. For example, a TerminalSymbol for the string "Foo" would evaluate the input string and signify success if it beings with "Foo", and signify failure if it does not. More complex evaluations are made possible through the use of regular expression patterns, which the TerminalSymbol class also supports. A TerminalSymbol also has no child rules, which reflects the meaning of its key - it represents the terminal point of a syntax rule evaluation.

A NonTerminalSymbol represents a grouping of rules which usually consists of multiple TerminalSymbols and other NonTerminalSymbols. A NonTerminalSymbol can be thought of as a shortcut through which a rule path can appear in different locations within the grammar without having to duplicate the logic. Unlike the TerminalSymbol, the NonTerminalSymbol class exposes a Rules collection; the contents of this collection defines the order in which the grammatical rules are evaluated.

A syntax rule is a concrete expression of a production rule of the grammar. Each type of rule represents a logical "operator" which defines the context for the evaluations performed by the TerminalSymbol. These rules make it possible to utilize familiar computer science concepts such as OR, AND, NAND, as well as repetition and optional evaluation. The following table provides a brief description of each type of rule:
Rule (see SyntaxRuleType enumeration) Description
Alternation
Synonymous with a logical 'OR' operator. Each sub-rule is evaluated until one succeeds, in which case the rule is satisfied. If all sub-rules fail, the alternation rule fails. As soon as one rule succeeds, the matching text is consumed and execution returns.
(see AlternationRule)
Concatenation
Each sub-rule is evaluated in the order in which they appear within the collection. If any sub-rule fails, the concatenation rule fails. As each rule succeeds, the matching text is consumed so that the next sub-rule evaluates the remaining text.
(see ConcatenationRule)
Conjunction
Synonymous with a logical 'AND' operator. Each sub-rule is evaluated against the same input text, so that the same text is checked against multiple conditions. If any sub-rule fails, the conjunction rule fails. If all rules succeed, the match which yielded the longest string of characters is consumed and execution returns.
(see ConjunctionRule)
Optional
Synonymous with a while loop which may contain zero or one iterations. Contains only one sub-rule, which is evaluated once; if each child rule of that sub-rule succeeds, the optional rule succeeds and execution returns. If the first terminal rule encountered fails, the optional rule fails, but no error is generated, and execution returns without consuming any of the input text. The Optional rule is a special case of the Repetition rule with a minimum of zero and a maximum of one.
(see OptionalRule)
Repetition
Synonymous with a for loop which contains one or more iterations. Contains only one sub-rule, which is evaluated n times, where n is defined by the minimum and maximum values for the rule. If the sub-rule succeeds at least as many times as the minimum requires, it succeeds, and fails if it does not. The number of iterations is dependent on the maximum, and the maximum can remain undefined, which causes the sub-rule to be evaluated until it fails.
(see RepetitionRule)
Negation
Synonymous with a logical 'NAND' operator. The NegationOperator rule is the direct opposite of the ConjunctionOperator rule; each sub-rule is evaluated without consuming matched text, and the negation rule succeeds only if all sub-rules fail.
(see NegationRule)
Terminal
Placeholder for the TerminalSymbol. All Rules collections must contain at least one Terminal rule.
(see TerminalRule)
NonTerminal
Placeholder for the NonTerminalSymbol.
(see NonTerminalRule)

Syntax analysis begins by calling the Parse method; this method analyzes each syntax rule defined for the grammar by recursively iterating the start symbol's Rules collection, consuming characters in the input string according to the properties of the TerminalSymbol which exists at each leaf node of the rule tree. The Parse method returns an instance of the ParseTree class, which encapsulates a tokenized representation of the text that was passed to the method. This ParseTree can be used by consumers to facilitate semantic interpretation, as well as code highlighting and code folding.
Because virtually every programming language can be defined by a context-free grammar, this class can be used to create a custom programming language.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar.TerminalBoundary
member.summary: Returns a TerminalBoundary instance which defines the parsing boundary for terminal rules associated with this Grammar.

remarks.p: A parsing boundary is essentially a separator which appears between significant terminal values. Typically a parsing boundary can be whitespace or characters which have special significance to the grammar. Parsing boundaries are necessary in order to identify terminal values unambiguously.
By default, the terminal boundary for this grammar is defined by the WhitespaceRegexPattern and each TerminalSymbol whose IsBoundary property returns true.

The TerminalBoundary's IsBoundary property is settable and can be set to true to make any terminal symbol act as a boundary for other symbols. When not explicitly set, each TerminalSymbol whose Comparison property returns 'Literal', and whose Value property returns a string that contains only one character where that character is neither a letter nor a digit, is also assumed to be a valid terminal parsing boundary for other terminal symbols. Setting the IsBoundary property negates its status as a terminal parsing boundary.

member.p:
Terminal parsing boundaries can be set at the following levels of the property resolution hierarchy, in order of descending priority:
The TerminalBoundary property of the TerminalSymbol itself.
The TerminalBoundary property of the SymbolGroup to which the terminal symbol belongs, if any.
The associated Grammar.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar.DefaultTerminalBoundaryRegexPattern
member.summary: Returns a regular expression pattern used by default to determine whether the character(s) following a parsed token constitute a valid parsing boundary for the token.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar.SymbolGroups
member.summary: Returns a collection which contains the SymbolGroup instances associated with this grammar.

remarks.p: Symbol groups are used to logically group terminal and/or non-terminal symbols which are similar in the context of the application. For example, if literal terminal symbols were created for the C# programming language keywords "using", "namespace", "class", and "this", the developer might add them to a group named "keywords".

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar.SyntaxValidationErrorAction
member.summary: Returns or sets a value which indicates whether syntax analysis continues after the first syntax validation error occurs.

remarks.p: By default, the syntax validation layer will continue after a syntax validation error so that multiple errors can be reported. This property can be used to prevent this, so that the validation operation terminates as soon as the first error is encountered.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar.StartSymbol
member.summary: Returns or sets a reference to the NonTerminalSymbol which defines the starting point for the Parse method.

remarks.p: When the Parse method is called, each production rule of the grammar is analyzed until all the input text is consumed, or until all rules have been evaluated. The StartSymbol defines the starting point for this analysis.
The StartSymbol property must be set to a non-null value prior to calling the Parse method, or an exception is thrown.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar.TerminalSymbols
member.summary: Returns a read-only collection which contains all TerminalSymbol instances defined for this grammar.

remarks.p: Terminal symbols are literal characters that can appear in the inputs to or outputs from the production rules of a formal grammar and are irreducible, i.e., cannot be broken down into "smaller" units.
TerminalSymbols are added to this collection automatically upon creation. Create new TerminalSymbol instances using the static Create method.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar.PrioritySymbols
member.summary: Returns a collection of terminal and non-terminal symbols which are given an opportunity to match the input text before production rules are evaluated.

remarks.p: The lexing/parsing process begins when the Parse method is called, causing the production rules defined for this grammar to be evaluated, in the order determined by the StartSymbol's Rules collection. The PrioritySymbols collection makes it possible for the developer to "insert" a rule at every location within the rule tree, so that symbols which are valid anywhere within the input text can be evaluated without having to explicitly define rules for them within the rule tree.

A good example of the use of PrioritySymbols is a comment line in the C# programming language. A comment line in C# begins with a double-slash ('//'), can be followed by virtually anything at all, and is terminated by a newline. This is easily expressed by the regular expression "//.*". Without the use of the PrioritySymbols collection, the developer would have to add an optional rule (containing a terminal rule with this regular expression) for virtually every rule in the rule tree in order to support comment lines within the code.

The PrioritySymbols collection can be thought of as an OptionalRule containing one AlternationRule, with each member of the collection being a sub-rule of that AlternationRule. If the rule defined by any member of this collection is satisfied, the text is consumed and optionally tokenized. The process continues until all rules (as defined by the members of this collection) fail, at which point syntax analysis continues from the next rule in the rule tree.

To avoid performance issues, it is recommended that any NonTerminalSymbols added to this collection contain a TerminalRule close to the beginning of its rule tree, so that the determination of whether the current input text matches the symbol can be made quickly. This is especially important because the PrioritySymbols are evaluated frequently as compared to other symbols.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar.NonTerminalSymbols
member.summary: Returns a collection of the non-terminal symbols which define this grammar.

remarks.p: A NonTerminalSymbol is a symbol of the grammar which can be replaced by some combination of terminal and non-terminal symbols.
A NonTerminalSymbol exposes a Rules collection to which syntax rules are added, thus defining the syntax for the grammar.
The StartSymbol property references a NonTerminalSymbol which defines the starting point for parse operations.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar.WhitespaceParsingMode
member.summary: Returns or sets a value indicating the manner in which whitespace character sequences are handled by the syntax analysis layer.

remarks.p: By default, whitespace characters are automatically consumed without analysis by the syntax validation layer, so that whitespace characters are effectively insignificant. If a grammar needs to explicitly evaluate whitespace, this property can be used to switch off automatic consumption, thus allowing whitespace to be tokenized, and allowing syntax validation errors to be reported when whitespace is encountered at invalid locations within the text.

In situations where whitespace should usually be disregarded, but is explicitly expected to appear at certain locations within the text being analyzed, the WhitespaceRegexSymbol property can be used to create a TerminalRule which will enforce the presence of whitespace at the designated locations.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar.WhitespaceRegexPattern
member.summary: Returns the regular expression pattern used to identify whitespace by the syntax analysis layer.

remarks.p: By default, the pattern '[\s\n\t]+' is used, which matches the ASCII characters 9 (horizontal tab), 10 (line feed), 13 (carriage return), and 32 (space). This property can be set to any valid regular expression pattern to change the definition of whitespace for this grammar.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar.WhitespaceRegexSymbol
member.summary: Returns a TerminalSymbol based on the value of the WhitespaceRegexPattern property, which can be used to match whitespace characters.

remarks.p: When the WhitespaceParsingMode is set to 'Automatic', whitespace characters are automatically parsed out of the text being analyzed. If a syntax rule expects whitespace at a specific location, it would fail to find it since it would have already been parsed and consumed. This property can be used to create a TerminalRule which is recognized by the syntax analysis layer so that it does not automatically parse out whitespace, allowing the rule for this symbol to be analyzed. This allows for whitespace to be ignored most of the time, while still providing a way to require whitespace at specific locations.

Since it is usually desirable to omit tokens which represent whitespace from the resulting output, the instance returned from this property is created with a value of false for the 'generatesToken' parameter. If the application requirements are such that whitespace should be tokenized, set the WhitespaceParsingMode property to 'Explicit', and add terminal rules for enforcing the presence of whitespace characters where required.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar.NewLine
member.summary: Returns or sets the character string which is used to represent new lines in text which is analyzed by the syntax validation layer.

remarks.p: In the case where the NewLine property is not explicitly set, the input string is searched for the presence of typical newline character sequences, i.e., '\r\n' and '\n'. Upon detection of the first newline, the value is cached and assumed to be the line delimiting character. This behavior can be overriden by explicitly setting the NewLine property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Grammar.Name

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.NonTerminalSymbol
member.summary: A grammar symbol which is composed of some combination of terminal and nonterminal symbols; also known as a syntactic variable.

remarks.p: A non-terminal symbol is basically a container for production rules and terminal symbols. The rule tree defined by a non-terminal symbol can be placed at multiple locations within the rule tree, providing a mechanism by which to avoid duplication of logic.

Consider the C# programming language concept of identifiers. Syntactic rules apply to what constitutes a valid identifier - it must begin with either an alphabetic character or underscore, followed by the same or one or more integers, and not be a keyword. In order to define a production rule that unambiguously identifies such strings, several criteria are necessary; the resulting rule tree looks something like this: Identifier -> ConcatenationOperator -> Matches regex pattern "^[a-zA-Z_][a-zA-Z0-9_]*" -> NotAKeyword -> NegationOperator -> AlternationOperator -> "using" -> "namespace" -> "class" -> "public|private|protected|internal" -> ... As evidenced by the above example, a fairly extensive rule hierarchy is necessary to express even something as simple as an identifier. Considering that a full definition for the C# programming language requires checks for an identifier in dozens or perhaps hundreds of places within the rule tree, the benefit of providing a means by which a "shortcut" form of expression can be used should be obvious.

member.param: The NonTerminalSymbol to test.

member.summary: Returns the string representation of this object.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.NonTerminalSymbol.Grammar
member.summary: Returns a reference to the associated Grammar.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.NonTerminalSymbol.Rules
member.summary: Returns a collection of SyntaxRule instances which describe the syntax rules for this NonTerminalSymbol.

remarks.p: The syntax for a grammar is defined by its production rules; the production rules for a grammar are exposed via the Rules collection of the grammar's StartSymbol.

The grammar's StartSymbol property references a NonTerminalSymbol which defines the starting point for parse operations. The order in which these rules are evaluated is determined by the contents of this collection. Each rule therein is analyzed by recursively analyzing descendant rules until a TerminalRule is encountered. A TerminalRule has no rules of its own; its purpose is to perform the actual parsing to determine whether the current input is valid.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.NonTerminalSymbol.CircularReferences
member.summary: Returns a collection containing the NonTerminalSymbol instances which refer to this instance.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.NonTerminalSymbol.HasCircularReference
member.summary: Returns a boolean value indicating whether this NonTerminalSymbol contains a descendant rule which refers either directly or indirectly back to this rule.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.NonTerminalSymbol.RequiredTerminalSymbol
member.summary: Returns or sets a reference to a TerminalSymbol for which a token must be produced in order to disambiguate this NonTerminalSymbol from other ones which begin with similar rules.

remarks.p: If two or more NonTerminalRules contain the same first terminals, the parser cannot distinguish between them until it encounters a token which is disallowed by one of the rules. For example, consider two rules, X = (A, B, C) and Y = (A, B, D), both belonging to an optional rule, and an input string of "A B D". Assuming rule X is evaluated before rule Y, the parser will assume that the input is invalid when it encounters the "C", and report errors, since rule X successfully parsed the first terminal, but not all of them. Assigning the TerminalSymbol for rule C to the RequiredTerminalSymbol property of rule X allows the parser to look ahead to determine whether the minimum number of required terminals have been matched; using this example, it will revert any consumed input once it determines that rule C has not been satisfied, and then move on to rule Y, which will parse the input successfully.
When no value is assigned to the RequiredTerminalSymbol property, the TerminalSymbol for the first TerminalRule is used to determine whether the rule partially succeeds.
The RequiredTerminalSymbol property is only used when this NonTerminalSymbol's rule is a sub-rule of an optional or alternation rule.

member.summary: Adds a new SyntaxRule to this collection with a RuleType of 'Terminal'.
member.param: The TerminalSymbol associated with the rule.
member.returns: The created SyntaxRule.

remarks.p: A terminal rule represents the endpoint of a production rule. The terminal rule attempts to parse the input and if the attempt is successful, the matching characters are consumed and parsing continues. If the attempt fails, the parent rule is notified and determines whether an error is logged.
A terminal rule cannot have sub-rules; attempting to add members to the Rules collection of a SyntaxRule whose RuleType returns 'Terminal' results in an exception being thrown.

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.InvalidCircularReferenceException
member.summary: Thrown when the Parse method is called on a start symbol which contains a NonTerminalRule which has a circular reference that is not preceded by a TerminalRule.

remarks.p: A circular reference occurs when one NonTerminalRule contains another NonTerminalRule in its descendancy chain which refers back to the first NonTerminalRule. Such references are supported, but a necessary caviat is that a TerminalRule must appear in the descendancy chain before the circular reference. This is an anti-recursion measure; if, for example, NonTerminalSymbol 'A' contains a rule for NonTerminalSymbol 'B', and 'B' contains a rule for 'A', infinite recursion would ensue as each rule refers to the other during the evaluation process. The recursion can be broken by an intervening TerminalRule, so that circular references are only evaluated in the event that the TerminalRule succeeds, and the state of the input string is changed.

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.InvalidDescendantRuleException
member.summary: Thrown when the first descendant rule of a ConjunctionRule or NegationRule is a NegationRule.

remarks.p: The first descendant rule of a ConjunctionRule or NegationRule must generate a token upon success; because a NegationRule does not, it is not valid as the first descendant of a ConjunctionRule or NegationRule.

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.InvalidDescendantOfConjunctionRuleException
member.summary: Thrown when a descendant rule of a ConjunctionRule or NegationRule is invalid.

remarks.p:
Each descendant rule of a ConjunctionRule or NegationRule must be one of the following rules in order to be valid:
TerminalRule
NonTerminalRule
AlternationRule
ConjunctionRule
NegationRule
This restriction is imposed so that each sub-rule only produces one token, which is necessary in order to compare each sub-rule to the others.

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalBoundary
member.summary: Provides a way to define a parsing boundary for a TerminalSymbol.

remarks.p: Usually a token must be followed by whitespace in order to distinguish it unambiguously from other tokens. For example, keywords (in the C# programming language) such as "using", "class", and "namespace" must be followed by either whitespace or special characters such as an open curly brace or semicolon. This nuance makes it possible to name a class "class1" - the parser knows that, since the phrase "class" is not followed by whitespace or a special character, it is distinguishable from the keyword, and as such is accepted as a valid identifier.

In order to make this behavior possible without requiring each production rule to explicitly include rules to account for it, the TerminalBoundary class provides a way to stipulate that the text parsed by a terminal must also be followed by a given string of characters in order for the rule to succeed.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalBoundary.Pattern
member.summary: Returns or sets the regular expression pattern which is evaluated to determine whether a parsed string contains the required boundary.

remarks.p: The Pattern property and the TerminalSymbols property are intended to be mutually exclusive, i.e., only one or the other should be used, but not both. In cases where both are set, the Pattern property takes precedence.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalBoundary.TerminalSymbols
member.summary: Returns a list of the TerminalSymbol instances which are evaluated to determine whether a parsed string contains the required boundary.

remarks.p: The TerminalSymbols property and the Pattern property are intended to be mutually exclusive, i.e., only one or the other should be used, but not both. In cases where both are set, the Pattern property takes precedence.
When the Pattern property is not set, and the list of TerminalSymbols contains one or more elements, the input string is evaluated by each TerminalSymbol in that list until the first match is made.

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol
member.summary: An irreducible element of the associated Grammar which can appear in the inputs to or outputs from the production rules of the grammar.

remarks.p: A terminal symbol can be a literal string or a regular expression. This literal string or regular expression is compared to strings in the text being analyzed by the syntax analysis layer when determining whether a statement is valid in the context of the associated grammar.

A terminal symbol represents the terminal point for a production rule. Production rules such as ConcatenationOperator, AlternationOperator, SyntacticFactor, etc. can be likened to logical tokens, whereas a terminal symbol does the actual character matching. All production rules must produce a rule tree which contains at least one TerminalRule as a leaf node, or an exception is thrown when the grammar's Parse method is called.

member.summary: Returns a reference to the associated Grammar.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.MatchingSymbol
member.summary: Returns the TerminalSymbol which matches this terminal symbol, or null if this terminal symbol is not matched.

remarks.p: The MatchingSymbol property can be used to pair symbols which are complementary, with one symbol representing the starting point for a block of content and the other representing the endpoint. For example, many programming languages use character pairs such as open and close parentheses, curly braces, and square brackets to enclose code fragments. The MatchingSymbol property makes it possible to pair such symbols, so that grammar consumers can easily implement things like brace matching and code folding.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.Value
member.summary: Returns the value associated with this terminal symbol.

remarks.p: When a string is compiled against the associated Grammar, this value is used to compare values in the string being compiled. The manner in which the values are compared is determined by the value of the Comparison property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.Description
member.summary: Returns or sets the description associated with this terminal symbol.

remarks.p: The Description property is intended to be used to provide a brief description of the tokens generated by this symbol.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.Comparison
member.summary: Returns a value which determines the manner in which values in the string being compiled are compared against this terminal symbol.

remarks.p: Terminal symbols support three types of character matching: literal, both with and without regard to character casing, and regular expression.

For example, to create a terminal symbol which matches text containing only alphabetic characters, set the Comparison property to 'RegularExpression', and assign the value '[a-zA-Z]*' to the Value property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.GeneratesToken
member.summary: Returns a boolean value indicating whether this symbol causes a token to be generated when it is used to parse output during syntactic analysis.

remarks.p: By default, when text is matched by a terminal symbol, that text is removed from the input and a token is generated for it in the resulting ParseTree. In cases where it is desirable to enforce the presence of the text represented by the terminal symbol, but prevent the resulting token from appearing in the ParseTree, this property can be set to false.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.TerminalSymbol.IsBoundary
member.summary: Returns or sets a value which determines whether this terminal symbol's Value can be considered to be a parsing boundary for other TerminalSymbols.

remarks.p: This property is only used when the associated Grammar's TerminalBoundary is not explicitly set.

When the associated Grammar's default parse boundary checking mechanism is initialized, terminal symbols whose IsBoundary property returns true are included, so that such symbols can act as a parsing boundary for other terminal symbols.
Terminal boundaries are not checked for TerminalSymbols whose IsBoundary property returns true, unless the symbol has a boundary explicitly defined.

By default, terminal symbols which meet the following criteria are used when a terminal boundary is evaluated:
The Comparison property returns either 'Literal' or 'LiteralIgnoreCase'.
The Value property contains only one character.
The string returned from the Value property is neither a letter nor a digit.

remarks.p: In the case where the NewLine property is not explicitly set, the input string is searched for the presence of typical newline character sequences, i.e., '\r\n' and '\n'. Upon detection of the first newline, the value is cached and assumed to be the line delimiting character. This behavior can be overriden by explicitly setting the NewLine property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Importing.GrammarImporter.Tokens
member.summary: Returns an enumerator containing the StatementToken instances which comprise the set of all strings found within the associated script.

remarks.p: This enumerator contains tokens for all parsed strings, appearing in the same order in which they appear in the string passed to the Load method. It can be used to format the script.

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Importing.GrammarNotation
member.summary: Encapsulates the properties of the notation used to represent a grammar definition.

remarks.p: A grammar notation definition is used to define the string values which identify reserved symbols within the grammar, for example, the assignment operator or end-of-statement marker.

By default, the GrammarImporter class expects input that conforms to the Extended Backup-Naur Form definition, as standardized in 1996 by the ISO/IEC 14977 specification (visit the Internation Organization for Standardization website for details).

In cases where the developer wants to use different symbols to denote assignments, logical operators, special sequences, comments, end-of-statement markers, etc., a class can be derived from this one, and the applicable properties overridden. That instance is then passed to the GrammarImporter class constructor when creating the object.
Note that all property values for the derived class must be unique, as ambiguity in this regard makes it impossible to reliably parse script content.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Importing.GrammarNotation.TerminalSymbolDeclarationIdentifier
member.summary: Returns the token which is used to signify that the following statement is to be interpreted as a TerminalSymbol declaration.

remarks.p: When a literal string is detected within the grammar script, it is implied to refer to a TerminalSymbol; the first occurrence of the literal string triggers creation of a TerminalSymbol instance, and subsequent occurrences refer to that instance.

No mechanism exists in the EBNF specification by which a token can be declared to identify a literal string so that it can be referred to elsewhere in the script. The TerminalSymbolDeclarationIdentifier property makes it possible to mark an assignment statement in the script as a terminal symbol declaration, so that a mnemonic can be used to reference a literal string anywhere in the script. This mnemonic is interpreted by subsequent statements as a reference to the TerminalSymbol whose value is the literal string that was assigned to the mnemonic in the declaration statement

The following statement is an example of a terminal symbol declaration:
?TERMINAL_SYMBOL? AnyNumber = ?REGEX? "[0-9]+";

As seen in the example, a terminal declaration statement must be in the form
[Special sequence symbol] [Terminal symbol declaration identifier] [Special sequence symbol] [Identifier] [Assignment operator] [Literal string] [End of statement symbol]
Also note that the [Literal string] portion can be optionally preceded by a special sequence.

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Importing.GrammarStatement
member.summary: Encapsulates a production rule statement as parsed from a grammar definition script.

remarks.p: When a grammar definition script is parsed, each occurrence of the EndOfStatementSymbol marks the end of a grammar statement; a GrammarStatement instance is created for the content preceding that marker.
The resulting GrammarStatement is then tokenized, using the symbols as defined by the associated GrammarNotation. Each successfully parsed token appears as a member of the Tokens collection.

member.name: P:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Importing.TerminalSymbolToken.FromReference
member.summary: Returns a boolean value indicating whether this token was created by parsing a reference to a TerminalSymbolDeclaration.

remarks.p: TerminalSymbols are declared implicitly when a literal string is encountered for the first time within the grammar script; subsequent occurrences of that literal string are interpreted as a reference to the TerminalSymbol.

A TerminalSymbol can be explicitly declared by prefixing an identifier with the TerminalSymbolDeclarationIdentifier, enclosed within a pair of special sequence symbols. When a reference to such a declaration is encountered, the FromReference property returns true.

member.name: T:Infragistics.SyntaxParsing.Importing.SpecialSequence
member.summary: Represents a block of text that is enclosed between a pair of SpecialSequenceSymbols.

remarks.p: Text found within a special sequence block may or may not have significance to the GrammarImporter. Special sequence blocks which do have significance are handled accordingly by the importer; the ones that do not are added to the SpecialSequences collection, but not used internally by the importer. Such tokens will return 'Unknown' as the value of the SpecialSequenceType property.
